prior_works.title: Freedom of the Will and the Concept of a Person
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of volitional agency and personhood
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the volitional conception of agency—rooted in reflective endorsement and second‑order desires—that the paper uses to argue contemporary AI lacks the kind of will-dependent ethical agency required for personhood.

prior_works.title: On the Morality of Artificial Agents
prior_works.role: Canonical articulation of mechanistic artificial moral agency
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Represents the mechanistic account of artificial moral agents prevalent in AI ethics, serving as the foil the paper critiques as insufficient for ethically significant behavior.

prior_works.title: Robots Should Be Slaves
prior_works.role: Early, influential rejection of robot personhood
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Anticipates the paper’s core claim by arguing against granting moral personhood to AI and emphasizing human responsibility by design, which the paper deepens with a political-theoretic grounding.

prior_works.title: Group Agency: The Possibility, Design, and Status of Corporate Agents
prior_works.role: Theory of institutional agency and accountability design
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the institutional lens for shifting from individual (machine) agency to designed group agents, informing the paper’s move to conceive AI outcomes as products of political/institutional processes with tailored accountability mechanisms.

prior_works.title: Do Artifacts Have Politics?
prior_works.role: STS thesis that technologies embody political choices
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Underpins the paper’s claim that AI systems should be analyzed as concretizations of political decisions and power arrangements rather than as autonomous ethical agents.

prior_works.title: Analysing and Assessing Accountability: A Conceptual Framework
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a rigorous vocabulary for accountability relations (forums, standards, sanctions) that the paper repurposes to propose political and institutional routes to AI accountability.

prior_works.title: Fairness and Abstraction in Sociotechnical Systems
prior_works.authors: Andrew D. Selbst, danah boyd, Sorelle A. Friedler, Suresh Venkatasubramanian, Janet Vertesi
prior_works.role: Sociotechnical critique of decontextualized algorithmic ethics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how abstraction erases social and institutional context, reinforcing the paper’s argument to move beyond anthropomorphic agent-centric ethics toward analysis of AI as embedded in political processes.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—contrasting mechanistic versus volitional agency and rejecting AI personhood in ethically significant contexts while reframing AI as the outcome of political processes—synthesizes strands from philosophy, political theory, and STS. Frankfurt’s account of volitional agency defines personhood through reflective self-governance and second-order volitions, a bar current AI cannot meet. Against this volitional benchmark, Floridi and Sanders’ mechanistic model of artificial moral agency exemplifies a dominant AI-ethics approach that treats systems as agents by virtue of causal roles, which the paper argues is inadequate for ethically weighty judgment. Bryson’s early rejection of robot personhood prefigures the paper’s stance, but the present work extends it by grounding non-personhood not merely in prudential design choices but in a richer theory of agency and responsibility.
Winner’s thesis that artifacts embody politics enables the shift from anthropomorphic analysis to examining how AI materializes political decisions and power, while List and Pettit’s theory of group agency shows how accountability should be designed into institutions rather than projected onto machines. Bovens supplies the operative framework—forums, standards, and sanctions—for instituting accountability, matching the paper’s call for political mechanisms over ascriptions of machine blame. Finally, Selbst et al.’s sociotechnical critique of abstraction motivates the move beyond agent-centric ethics toward system-level, context-aware analysis. Together, these works directly scaffold the paper’s argument that, for ethically significant behavior, AI should not be treated as an ethical agent but as a politically constituted outcome requiring institutional accountability.
